Award.AwardTitle: Novel methods for the analysis of animal movement: spatial and temporal structure across scale SCIB conference; Charleston SC; Jan 3-7, 2012
Award.AbstractNarration: The quantification of animal movement is an important tool in diverse research disciplines within biology. For example, geneticists developing new mutants use locomotion to describe changes in phenotype for thousands of lines, neuroscientists use movement to understand how the brain works, and changes in animal migration patterns are providing understanding of the effects of global climate change. Endeavors ranging from the scale of the movements of cells within developing embryos to continental and ocean migration patterns are benefitting from new advances in computing, automated tracking, and imaging. However, many of the newest tools are being developed within academic laboratories and, even if offered freely, may require specialized skills in engineering to utilize. A second challenge for all such projects is the need to develop mathematical approaches to the analysis of the large data sets produced via automated tracking and movement assessment systems. Thus, advances in computing and sensor hardware have created unprecedented opportunities that are nonetheless unavailable to many biologists. As a first step to address this problem, we have organized a symposium where potential users can become aware of the new tools available. The program is designed to encourage interactions among the audience members and with invited speakers to create opportunities for collaboration and shared development that would not otherwise be possible. The symposium will include presentations by eleven speakers including one graduate student, four postdocs and junior fellows or faculty. The collection of speakers illustrates a major effort to recruit among the most important contributors to this integrative topic while simultaneously broadening the participation of under-represented groups at the interface of engineering and biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF award supported a scientific conference entitled, “Novel methods for the analysis of animal movement: spatial and temporal structure across scales”. The award supported participant costs and some travel expenses for eleven investigators to present in the symposium, which was held on January 4, 2012 at the annual conference for the Society of Integrative and Comparative Biology. The speakers included one graduate student, five postdocs, one assistant professor, one associate professor, and three full professors. In addition to the symposium, the society organized a complementary session of submitted talks on January 5, 2012. This session included presentations by ten speakers including graduate students, postdocs, and junior faculty.

The need for accurate measurements of animal motion is shared by many branches of biology, ranging from ecology to cell biology. Recent advances in computer vision, onboard motion tagging, satellite tracking, radar and other techniques have providing large and accurate data on the movements of organisms across a range of scales, from bacteria foraging in a drop of pond water to whales migrating across oceans. Some of these tools are available as plug-and-play combinations of hardware and software. However, many of the newest tools are developed within academic laboratories and, even if freely available, may require specialized skills in engineering to operate. A second challenge for all such projects is the need to develop mathematical approaches the large data sets produce via automated tracking and movement assessment. Thus, advances in computing and sensor hardware have created unprecedented opportunities that are nonetheless unavailable to many comparative biologists.

A synthetic symposium was organized to foster information transfer across disciplines and to provide guidance for tracking the further development of motion analysis approaches. Speakers covered a broad range of topics including genetics, development, biomechanics, behavior, ecology, functional morphology, and neuroscience. The research described approaches to motion analysis in diverse organisms such as nematodes, insects, fishes, birds, and mammals. Some of the research covered in the talks was described in news articles in the journal Science:

 DOI: 10.1126/science.335.6066.276-a

DOI: 10.1126/science.335.6066.276-b

 The full list of symposium talks with links to the abstracts can be found at the following url: http://www.sicb.org/meetings/2012/symposia/movement.php
